importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the Hamas-led attack on Israel that resulted in the death of Sergeant Major Tal Haimi, marking a pivotal moment in the Israel-Hamas conflict and the subsequent hostage situation.
This is the date the US-proposed Gaza ceasefire deal was signed, setting a timeline for the return of hostages and triggering diplomatic and military responses regarding compliance.
The date of the latest identification of the deceased hostage, and a key update in the ongoing implementation of the ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.approximateTimeFrameStart: immediately after ceasefire goes into effect
importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The ceasefire agreement required Hamas to return all deceased hostages within 72 hours, creating a critical deadline that has been repeatedly delayed and is now under scrutiny.

keyTakeAways: Israeli authorities have identified the body of Sergeant Major Tal Haimi, a 41-year-old Israeli soldier killed during the Hamas attack on October 7, 2023, while defending a kibbutz.
Haimi is the 13th deceased hostage to be returned and identified since the ceasefire deal was signed on October 9, 2025, and is survived by his wife, four children, father, and sister.
The return and identification of deceased hostages are central to the implementation of the US-brokered ceasefire, which requires Hamas to hand over all deceased hostages within 72 hours.
Hamas has reportedly failed to return all bodies, with one body previously misidentified as an Israeli hostage—raising concerns about transparency and compliance.
Israeli officials, including Knesset Speaker Amir Ohana, have stressed the necessity of fulfilling the hostage return clause 'one way or another'.

The Trump administration has threatened to 'eradicate' Hamas if it violates the ceasefire, and US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner held high-level meetings with Israeli military leaders to address compliance and implementation.
The ceasefire is under strain due to accusations of violations and delays in body transfers, highlighting broader tensions in the diplomatic and humanitarian aspects of the conflict.
The Hostages and Missing Families Forum has expressed deep condolences to Haimi’s family, emphasizing the emotional and psychological impact of the prolonged uncertainty.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Israeli authorities have identified the remains of Sergeant Major Tal Haimi, a 41-year-old Israeli soldier killed during the October 7, 2023, Hamas attack on a kibbutz, as the 13th deceased hostage to be returned under the US-brokered ceasefire agreement. Haimi, survived by his wife, four children, father, and sister, is a symbol of both personal tragedy and the broader struggle over compliance with the ceasefire terms. Hamas has faced criticism for failing to return all deceased hostages within the required 72-hour window, with one body previously misidentified as Israeli, raising concerns about transparency. The U.S. administration, led by President Donald Trump, has threatened to 'eradicate' Hamas if it violates the agreement, while U.S. envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner have held high-level talks with Israeli military leaders to ensure compliance. Israeli officials, including Knesset Speaker Amir Ohana, insist the return of all deceased hostages is non-negotiable. The Hostages and Missing Families Forum has expressed deep sorrow to Haimi’s family, emphasizing the enduring emotional pain of prolonged uncertainty.
title: Israel Identifies Body of Deceased Hostage as Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
